metadata.title: SIMPLE IRA Projected Balance & Comparison Calculator
metadata.description: Estimate future SIMPLE IRA balances, employer contributions, and inflation-adjusted purchasing power. Supports typical SIMPLE employer options (match or 2% nonelective) and includes regulatory and accuracy guidance.

future_balance.label: Projected balance and retirement income
future_balance.description: Projects account value at retirement using annual compounding net of explicit annual fees, sums employee + employer contributions, and provides inflation-adjusted balance and estimated sustainable withdrawal income.

fv_contribs.label: Future value of a series of annual contributions

fields.label: Expected annual nominal investment return (before fees)

introduction: This calculator projects future SIMPLE IRA account balances using user inputs for current balance, annual employee contribution, employer contribution approach (match or 2% nonelective), expected returns, fees, and inflation. It produces both nominal and inflation-adjusted estimates and an initial sustainable withdrawal estimate.

The tool models employer contributions using common SIMPLE plan conventions: a dollar-for-dollar match up to a chosen percent of compensation or a 2% nonelective contribution. Users should confirm their plan's exact employer formula and IRS limits when finalizing plans.
methodology: We forecast balances with annual compounding using a net annual return equal to expected nominal return minus explicit annual fees provided by the user. Employee and employer contributions are treated as annual end-of-year contributions for the series calculation.

Employer contribution is estimated as either (employee compensation × match percent) when the employer match option is selected or (employee compensation × 2%) for the nonelective option. This simplifies plan variations; please cross-check against your plan document.
how_is_calculated: Net annual return = (expected nominal return %) - (annual fee %).
Future value of current balance = current_balance × (1 + net_return)^years.
Future value of annual contributions = annual_total_contrib × ((1 + net_return)^years − 1) / net_return, with fallback to annual_total_contrib × years if net_return is 0.
Projected nominal balance = future value of current balance + future value of contributions.
Inflation-adjusted balance = projected nominal balance / (1 + inflation %) ^ years.
Estimated initial sustainable withdrawal = projected nominal balance × (withdrawal rate %).
examples: Example: $10,000 current balance, $15,000 employee contribution, $50,000 compensation, 3% employer match, 6% return, 0.5% fees, 30 years: calculator returns a nominal projected balance and an inflation-adjusted equivalent, plus cumulative contributions and initial withdrawal estimate.
Edge case note: if net return equals zero, the calculator sums contributions linearly for growth (avoids division by zero).

faqs.question: Does this tool enforce IRS SIMPLE IRA contribution limits?
faqs.answer: No. This calculator does not automatically enforce annual IRS contribution caps or catch-up rules. You must ensure your entered employee contribution does not exceed applicable IRS limits for the tax year and whether catch-up contributions apply.

faqs.question: How are employer contributions estimated?
faqs.answer: If 'match' is selected the employer contribution is estimated as employee compensation × employer match percent. If 'nonelective' is selected the employer contribution is estimated as 2% of compensation. Actual plan formulas may vary; use this as an estimate and verify with plan documents.

faqs.question: Are fees and inflation included?
faqs.answer: Yes. The calculator subtracts the annual fee percentage from the expected nominal return to compute a net return, and it separately adjusts the projected balance to today’s dollars using the inflation rate you provide.

faqs.question: How accurate are the withdrawal estimates?
faqs.answer: Withdrawal estimates are simple initial-year projections using the chosen withdrawal rate. They do not model sequence-of-return risk, taxes, required minimum distributions, or changing spending patterns. Use them for planning only.

faqs.question: What if my net return is zero?
faqs.answer: The model falls back to linear accumulation of contributions when net return equals zero to avoid divide-by-zero errors. This is an approximation and noted in the example section.

glossary.definition: A retirement plan for small employers that allows employee salary deferrals and requires specified employer contributions (either matching or nonelective).
An employer contribution made for eligible employees regardless of whether they defer; the SIMPLE nonelective option commonly uses a 2% of compensation rate.
Expected nominal return minus explicit annual fees used in this model; does not include taxes or transaction costs unless entered as fees.
Projected balance converted into today's purchasing power by dividing by (1 + inflation_rate)^years.
A planning assumption for the percentage of the portfolio that can be withdrawn in the first retirement year; does not guarantee sustainability under all market conditions.

summary: Use this calculator to estimate future SIMPLE IRA balances and compare employer contribution approaches. It is designed for planning and educational use, not as tax or legal advice.
Validate all inputs against plan documents and current IRS rules before making contribution decisions.
